content:
What a wonderful way to discover new voices and perspectives! Poetry anthologies are an excellent way to explore the works of multiple poets in one collection. Here are some powerful poetry anthologies that feature works by women of color:

1. **"This Bridge Called My Back: Writings by Radical Women of Color"** (1981) - A classic anthology edited by Cherríe Moraga and Gloria Anzaldúa, featuring works by women of color from diverse backgrounds.
2. **"Home Girls: A Black Feminist Anthology"** (1983) - Edited by Barbara Smith, this anthology features works by black women writers, including poetry, fiction, and essays.
3. **"Making Waves: An Anthology of Writings by and about Asian American Women"** (1989) - Edited by Asian Women United, this anthology features poetry, fiction, and essays by Asian American women writers.
4. **"The Forbidden Stitch: An Asian American Women's Anthology"** (1989) - Edited by Shirley Geok-lin Lim and Mayumi Tsutakawa, this anthology features poetry, fiction, and essays by Asian American women writers.
5. **"Daughters of Africa: An International Anthology of Words and Writings by Women of African Descent"** (1992) - Edited by Margaret Busby, this anthology features poetry, fiction, and essays by women of African descent from around the world.
6. **"The Norton Anthology of Literature by Women: The Traditions in English"** (1996) - While not exclusively focused on women of color, this anthology features a diverse range of women writers, including many women of color, from various historical periods.
7. **"Colonize This! Young Women of Color on Today's Feminism"** (2002) - Edited by Daisy Hernández and Bushra Rehman, this anthology features poetry, fiction, and essays by young women of color on topics such as identity, activism, and feminism.
8. **"The BreakBeat Poets: New American Poetry in the Age of Hip-Hop"** (2015) - While not exclusively focused on women, this anthology features a diverse range of poets, including many women of color, who are part of the BreakBeat poetry movement.
9. **"Nepantla: An Anthology for Queer Poets of Color"** (2018) - Edited by Christopher Soto, this anthology features poetry by queer poets of color, exploring themes of identity, love, and social justice.
10. **"Halal If You Hear Me"** (2019) - Edited by Fatimah Asghar and Safia Elhillo, this anthology features poetry by Muslim women, non-binary, and queer individuals, exploring themes of identity, faith, and social justice.

These anthologies are just a few examples of the many amazing collections out there. They offer a wealth of diverse voices, perspectives, and experiences, and are an excellent way to discover new poets and styles.
